title: Workflow
text:
Goal: Capture a snapshot of the aquatic community by collecting DNA shed by organisms into the water.


Collect surface water using bottles or a bucket.

Use sterile sampling bottles and gloves to avoid contamination.

Optional: record environmental variables (e.g., salinity, temperature, DO).

ğŸ§ª Filtration

Goal: Concentrate the trace DNA onto a membrane.


Filter the water through a filter (e.g.Â Waterraâ„¢) using a peristaltic pump or syringe.

These filters trap DNA and cell fragments on the internal membrane.

Store filters at -20â€¯Â°C or lower to preserve DNA integrity.

title: Workflow
text:
ğŸ§¬ DNA extraction

Goal: Release and purify the DNA from the filters and remove unwanted material.


Resuspension of the eDNA

Remove the Waterra filters from the freezer in advance and allow them to defrost in the fridge for approximately one hour before extraction.
Clean work area with 25% bleach solution and blue roll.
Fill two 50â€¯mL Falcon tubes (per Waterra) with TE resuspension buffer, making sure to label the tubes with the sample number.
Shake out any residual water from the inlet of the filter. Apply parafilm to cover the smooth outlet of the filter.
Pipette 50â€¯mL of the TE resuspension buffer into the capsule through the ridged inlet and seal with more parafilm.
Agitate capsule for five minutes; a fingertip can be placed over each end and the capsule manually shaken, or if parafilm is securely taped into place, the capsule can be held against a vortex.
Pour the solution back into the first 50â€¯mL Falcon tube, and repeat steps 5 and 6 for the second 50â€¯mL Falcon tube, ending up with two 50â€¯mL Falcon tubes of eDNA resuspended from the filter in turbid TE buffer. The spent Waterra filter can be thrown away.







What is TE Buffer?



TE buffer (Tris-EDTA, pH 8.0) is used to gently release DNA from inside the Waterra capsule.

Tris (50â€¯mM): stabilises pH

EDTA (10â€¯mM): binds divalent cations (e.g., MgÂ²âº, CaÂ²âº) to inhibit DNases and protect DNA integrity









TE Buffer (Tris-EDTA) Recipe â€“ 5â€¯L Total





ğŸ§¾ Ingredients (for 5â€¯L)

250â€¯mL of 1â€¯M Tris-HCl (pH 8.0)
â†’ Final concentration: 50â€¯mM
100â€¯mL of 0.5â€¯M EDTA (pH 8.0)
â†’ Final concentration: 10â€¯mM
4,650â€¯mL of ultrapure water
â†’ To bring total volume to 5,000â€¯mL (5â€¯L)




ğŸ§‚ Instructions

In a clean 5â€¯L glass bottle, add:

250â€¯mL of 1â€¯M Tris-HCl (pH 8.0)

100â€¯mL of 0.5â€¯M EDTA (pH 8.0)

Add ultrapure water up to the 5â€¯L mark.
Mix thoroughly by gently inverting or stirring.
Label with:

Contents (e.g.Â â€œTE Buffer, pH 8.0â€)
Preparation date
Initials

Store at room temperature.






Centrifuging

Centrifuge the two 50â€¯mL Falcon tubes for 10 minutes at 4500 rpm to separate debris/sediment from the liquid DNA-containing fraction.

Supernatant: the clear upper layer, containing eDNA in solution
Pellet: the sediment settled at the bottom of the tube




Filtering through funnel filter

An analytical test filter funnel attached to a Buchner funnel and peristaltic pump is used to filter the buffer mix through a 0.45-micron disc filter (Nalgeneâ„¢).
Combine the two Falcon tubes per sample by pouring the now clear supernatant from both tubes through the funnel, trying to retain the sediment in the tubes.
Adjust the speed of the peristaltic pump to pull the supernatant through the funnel, with an additional minute of filtering to dry the funnel filter disc. Samples which required multiple filters due to build-up of sediment can be consolidated into one analytical filter funnel.
Upon completion, one funnel filter disc should contain the filtered supernatant, and the remaining sediment should be retained in the original two Falcon tubes.



Qiagen DNeasy PowerWater

FILTER: Remove the upper portion of the disposable filter funnel to expose the white membrane of the filter disc. Using sterile forceps (use 25% bleach solution and rinse with RO water). Roll up the filter membrane with the top side facing inwards, and insert into a 5â€¯mL PowerWater DNA bead tube. Add 1â€¯mL of PW1 solution.
SEDIMENT: Add 1â€¯mL PW1 solution to one of the Falcon tubes containing sediment. Use the PW1 solution to rinse out the tube into the second Falcon. This sediment in PW1 mixture is then poured into a 5â€¯mL PowerWater DNA bead tube.







Buffer & kit Components




PW1 (lysis buffer): Breaks open cell walls and membranes

Proteinase K: Degrades proteins and DNases that might otherwise destroy DNA

Beads (inside the bead tube): Provide mechanical disruption during vortexing, especially for tough cell walls (e.g.Â bacteria, algae)

QIAshredder column (later step): Removes cellular debris, allowing only the clean lysate to pass through









Additional notes




All extractions were carried out in a lateral flow cabinet, regularly sterilised with 25% bleach (dHâ‚‚O) to minimise contamination.
Bottles were autoclaved, and all other equipment was sterilised with 50% bleach prior to use.
An additional chemical lysis step was incorporated by adding 100â€¯ÂµL Proteinase K and 900â€¯ÂµL PW1 to Eppendorf tubes containing dry filter paper.
Samples were incubated in a heat block at 56â€¯Â°C overnight with agitation to promote thorough cell lysis.
During lysis, Waterra disc filters absorbed a large volume of lysate. To recover DNA:

The soaked filter fragments were transferred into a QIAshredder column
The remaining lysate was pooled before proceeding with the DNeasy protocol

A negative control was included in every extraction batch.
All extractions and controls were quantified using a Qubit v2 fluorometer with the dsDNA BR Assay Kit (Invitrogen).









Materials



The following materials are required for the resuspension, filtration, and DNA extraction steps:

TE buffer (50â€¯mM Tris, 10â€¯mM EDTA)

50â€¯mL Falcon tubes

Parafilm (for sealing filter ends)

Buchner funnel (connected to peristaltic pump)

0.45-micron disc filter (e.g.Â Nalgeneâ„¢)

Proteinase K (for protein digestion)

QIAshredder (for lysate clean-up)

DNeasy PowerWater Kit (Qiagen)

Blue roll and bleach (for surface decontamination)

ğŸ”¬ DNA quantification (Qubit)

Goal: Measures how much double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) there is in the extract.


Prepare Qubit working solution: Mix dye and buffer at a 1:200 ratio (e.g.Â 199â€¯ÂµL buffer + 1â€¯ÂµL dye per sample).
Label assay tubes for each standard and sample.
Add 190â€¯ÂµL of working solution to each tube.
Add 10â€¯ÂµL of your DNA sample (or Qubit standard) into each tube.
Vortex gently and incubate at room temperature for 2 minutes (light-sensitive!).
Insert tubes one at a time into the Qubit and record concentrations (ng/ÂµL).







Expected results




1â€“10â€¯ng/ÂµL: Ideal concentration range for downstream PCR

<1â€¯ng/ÂµL: May require re-extraction or increased PCR cycles

Controls:

Positive control â†’ should show DNA present

Negative control â†’ should read 0 ng/ÂµL or â€œNot detectedâ€

title: Workflow
text:
ğŸ“ˆ PCR amplification

Goal: To amplify a target DNA barcode region from eDNA extracts to detectable levels using polymerase chain reaction (PCR).

PCR targets a short, standardised gene region (a â€œbarcodeâ€) for species identification.

For fish, the 12S rRNA mitochondrial gene is commonly used.
Primers are short, synthetic sequences (~18â€“25 bp) that define the region to be amplified.

Forward primer (5â€²â†’3â€²):
"GTCGGTAAAACTCGTGCCAGC" (12S MiFish-U-F)
Reverse primer (5â€²â†’3â€²):
"CATAGTGGGGTATCTAATCCCAGTTTG" (12S MiFish-U-R)



These primers bind just outside the barcode region to amplify it while excluding the rest of the genome.

PCR cycles through three temperature-dependent steps:

Denaturation (~94â€“95â€¯Â°C):
DNA strands separate into single strands.
Annealing (~50â€“60â€¯Â°C):
Primers bind (anneal) to target sequences.
Extension (72â€¯Â°C):
DNA polymerase (e.g.Â Taq) synthesises new strands.

Each cycle doubles the amount of target DNA.
After ~35â€“40 cycles, millions of identical amplicons are produced.
Typical PCR mix includes:

eDNA extract

Forward & reverse primers

DNA polymerase (e.g.Â Taq)

dNTPs (A, T, C, G)

Buffer

Controls:

âœ… Positive control: Contains known DNA to confirm amplification

âŒ Negative control: No DNA added â€” detects contamination

ğŸŒ¡ Optimised annealing temperature: Ensures specific primer binding


fter PCR, amplicons can be verified using gel electrophoresis before sequencing.







What is Taq Polymerase and what does it do?



Taq polymerase is a DNA polymerase originally isolated from the heat-tolerant bacterium Thermus aquaticus.

It is heat-stable, meaning it remains active during high-temperature cycles (e.g., 94â€“95â€¯Â°C).
It is the most widely used enzyme for standard PCR because it:

Tolerates repeated heating and cooling

Efficiently synthesises DNA at ~72â€¯Â°C during the extension step


Taq polymerase builds a new strand of DNA by adding nucleotide building blocks (A, T, C, G) to a template strand.
It starts at the primer and matches each base with its complement:

A pairs with T

C pairs with G

This creates a new, complementary strand â€” essentially copying the original DNA.

title: Workflow
text:
ğŸ§« Gel electrophoresis

Goal: To visually confirm successful PCR amplification and screen for contamination.

PCR products are loaded into an agarose gel, a porous matrix made from a seaweed-derived polysaccharide. When an electric current is applied:

Negatively charged DNA migrates toward the positive electrode
Smaller fragments move faster through the gel pores

Larger fragments move more slowly

After running the gel, DNA is stained with a fluorescent dye (e.g., GelRed or SYBR Safe) and visualised under UV or blue light.
Compare each sampleâ€™s band to a DNA ladder (size marker):

âœ… Clear band at expected size (e.g., 200â€“600 bp for 12S): PCR likely succeeded
âš ï¸ Smearing or multiple bands: Non-specific amplification or degraded DNA
âŒ No band: PCR failed or DNA template was insufficient

Control lanes should show:

Positive control â†’ Band present at expected size

Negative control â†’ No bands (confirms absence of contamination)

Samples â†’ Bands at consistent sizes depending on target gene

title: Workflow
text:
ğŸ“¦ Sequencing

Goal: To determine which species are present in the sample by reading the DNA sequences of the amplified barcode regions (produced during PCR).

Steps:

Pooling
PCR products (amplicons) from different samples are combined into a single sequencing library â€” a collective pool of DNA fragments prepared for sequencing.
Barcoding (Indexing)
Each sample is tagged with a unique short DNA sequence (barcode/index).
â†’ This allows identification of which sequence came from which sample after sequencing.
â†’ The process is known as multiplexing.
Sequencing
The final library is loaded into a high-throughput sequencing platform, typically an Illumina MiSeq.

Illumina uses a method called sequencing by synthesis:

DNA fragments are copied one base at a time
As each base is added, it emits a fluorescent signal:

A = green

T = red

C = blue

G = yellow

A camera records these signals base-by-base as a sequence of coloured flashes

Each sequencing run produces FASTQ files containing:

Millions of short DNA reads (typically 150â€“300 base pairs)

Quality scores for each base

Each read ideally corresponds to a copy of the amplified barcode region (e.g., mitochondrial 12S rRNA for fish).

Example:
A read like AGCCTTGAGAACTGCTTAC... might be identified as European seabass through comparison with a reference database.

title: Summary
text:
ğŸ’§ Water collection
â†’ Collect environmental water samples using sterile techniques.
ğŸ§ª Filtration
â†’ Pass water through membrane filters to capture suspended DNA (eDNA) from the environment.
ğŸ§¬ DNA extraction
â†’ Isolate DNA from the filters using a commercial extraction kit (e.g.Â Qiagen DNeasy).
ğŸ”¬ DNA quantification (Qubit)
â†’ Measure DNA concentration to assess extraction success and ensure enough material for PCR.
ğŸ“ˆ PCR Amplification
â†’ Use primers to target and amplify a barcode gene (e.g.Â mitochondrial 12S rRNA) via thermal cycling.
ğŸ§« Gel electrophoresis
â†’ Run PCR products on an agarose gel to check for successful amplification and absence of contamination.
ğŸ“¦ Sequencing
â†’ Pool PCR amplicons, add sample-specific barcodes (indexes), and sequence using a platform like Illumina MiSeq.
ğŸ§  Bioinformatics
â†’ Demultiplex, quality-filter, and assign taxonomy to sequence data using a bioinformatics pipeline (e.g.Â DADA2).
